name: Vitamin B9 (Folate / Folic Acid)
summary: Vitamin B9, known as folate in its natural form and folic acid in its synthetic form, is an essential water-soluble B vitamin required for DNA synthesis, repair, and methylation, as well as red blood cell formation.
description: Folate plays a key role in one-carbon metabolism, supporting nucleotide biosynthesis and methylation reactions. Deficiency leads to megaloblastic anemia, elevated homocysteine, and in pregnancy, an increased risk of neural tube defects. Supplementation with folic acid is routinely recommended for women of childbearing potential. Folate may also support cardiovascular health, cognition, and mood regulation through its role in neurotransmitter synthesis. However, excessive folic acid intake may mask vitamin B12 deficiency.

metadata.natural_source: Leafy greens, legumes, citrus fruits, fortified grains, liver
metadata.fda_status: Approved vitamin; also available as dietary supplement

primary_indications: Prevention of neural tube defects in pregnancy
Supplementation in patients on folate-lowering drugs (e.g., methotrexate, phenytoin)
contraindications: Use with caution in pernicious anemia (may mask B12 deficiency)
monitoring_required: CBC and folate/B12 levels in patients with anemia

items: Treatment and prevention of folate deficiency
Prevention of neural tube defects in pregnancy
Adjunct in patients with high homocysteine
Support in certain psychiatric or cognitive conditions

sections.text: Folate functions as a coenzyme in one-carbon metabolism, required for DNA/RNA synthesis, methylation, and amino acid metabolism. Adequate folate supports neurotransmitter production, homocysteine regulation, and cell division.

adult.pregnancy: 400–800 mcg/day (supplementation recommended preconception through early pregnancy)

sections.pediatric: 50–300 mcg/day depending on age; higher doses for deficiency

items: Prescription formulations of folinic acid or L-methylfolate

sections.text: Improvement in anemia within 1–2 weeks; prevention of neural tube defects requires supplementation starting before conception.

serious: High doses may mask vitamin B12 deficiency, leading to neurologic damage

other: Do not rely on folic acid supplementation alone in B12 deficiency.
High doses (>1 mg/day) should be supervised by a clinician.

items.action: Folinic acid rescue may be required

items.risk: May lower folate levels, reduce drug efficacy

items: Serum folate and vitamin B12 levels

sections.pregnancy: Strongly recommended to prevent neural tube defects
sections.pediatrics: Safe at RDA levels; higher doses for deficiency under supervision
sections.geriatrics: Safe, though B12 deficiency should be ruled out

sections.text: Not required; supplementation may be stopped abruptly if no longer indicated.

items: Supplementation should begin before conception for maximum prevention of neural tube defects.
L-methylfolate is the active form and may be preferred in individuals with MTHFR polymorphisms.
Folate deficiency often presents alongside macrocytic anemia; always rule out vitamin B12 deficiency.
